11:13 am
PM

(jimpj -- nfi )

BE

Credit Suisse can provide the quick summary to save me the effort.

BE

■ FY15 EBITDA came in at $890m 10% below CS at $985m and 15% below
consensus $1.05bn. Net debt came in at $1.02bn, significantly higher than
CS at $370m and consensus at $643m. Miss vs CS driven by working
capital, higher tax and lower operating cash flows. The $0.4bn higher net
debt vs consensus is equivalent to £0.25-30/share.
■ No final dividend declared due to an underlying loss in H2. The company
has maintained the 35% DPS pay-out policy and we did not expect a final
dividend however the lack of dividend highlights the cash flow pressures at
the group.
■ Guidance: No changes to production (710-740 kt) and cost guidance (165c
gross, 135c net) that was provided in Jan. 2016 capex guided at $1bn (CS
$960m). Group focus on cutting costs and FCF and major unapproved
projects have been delayed by at least 1-2 years.

11:13 am
BE

■ Catalysts: Copper prices, ramp up of Antucoya and Centinela Concentrates,
project licensing.
■ Valuation: The company is trading on a 2016E EV/EBITDA of c10x or c9x at
spot prices, a significant premium to European peers. We forecast FCF
yields close to 0% and a DY of sub 1.5% in 2015-17 based on the company’s
35% payout ratio policy.

BE

And Canaccord.

BE

These were poor results, towards the bottom of a very wide consensus range.
Antofagasta had already reported 2015 copper production of 630,300t (down 11%), gold
production of 213,900oz (down 21%) and molybdenum production of 10,100t (up 8%) as
well as average cash costs before by-product credits of 181c/lb, down 1%, and net costs
of 150c/lb, up 5%. Given lower production and weaker realised prices (228c/lb copper
in 2015, off 24%), EBITDA fell significantly, to US$891M, down 58% from US$2,141M
in 2014, and relative to our forecast of US$1,078M and Bloomberg consensus of US
$1,035M (range US$877-1,481M). Eps on continuing operations was 0.6c, down 99%
from 42.8c in 2014 and relative to our eps forecast of 3.3c (Bloomberg consensus 7.8c,
range -9.6c to +28c). As expected, no final dividend was declared, given that the interim
payment of 3.1c exceeded the 35% minimum payout ratio set in the dividend policy. It’s
worth noting that the company did not give its usual collated consensus, saying that the
range was so wide as to render the consensus misleading. Net debt was US$1,024M,
worse than our US$985M forecast.

11:15 am
BE

And Stifel ..........

BE

Bottom line. Antofagasta shares have rallied over 40% since mid-January
2016 (vs. the FTSE Mining index up 23% over the same period) and at the
current share price of 534p are at a level close to our valuation price of 558p.
Whilst we are confident that Antofagasta remains the sleep easy long-term
macro copper investment with the shares likely to track copper prices in the
medium term, we think investors wishing to bank some profits following the
significant recovery in the sector year to date might want to consider taking
some money off the table following the last two months’ share price
performance. Antofagasta remains a stable cash flowing business with a
relatively strong balance sheet and offers investors relative safety in the
available copper investment landscape, in our view.

PM

So no real divi for the foreseeable

11:16 am
BE

As for the sector, there's any number of downgrades around advising a taking of profit.

BE

Actually, when I say "any number" I mean two.

BE

Haitong and Macquarie.

11:17 am
BE

Both arguing that it's a lovely rally, it really is, but without demand recovering it's not really built on anything.

BE

Here's Haitong.

BE

The sector has bounced but we remain soberly disciplined, and downgrade Glencore and BHP Billiton to NEUTRAL and Anglo American to SELL. Fundamentals were not as poor as sentiment in January, but equally are not as good as current iron ore prices suggest. In our view, what started as a short-covering rally in the stocks has turned into a wider covering of underweight positions by generalists, and this will run its course. We revisit the four key industry trends from our note “The Hangover” to see how the industry continues to deal with the aftermath of the commodity party of the past decade.

11:18 am
BE

The extreme pessimism at the start of 2016 seems to have passed, with generalists coming back to look at the sector now that it has rallied. We downgrade BHP, Glencore and Anglo American on valuation grounds following significant rebounds in these stocks; on current evidence we don’t see a surge in demand that would justify recent moves. Instead we continue to see a longer-term cycle evolving, driven by the four trends highlighted in our note “The Hangover” which will set up the next cycle over the longer term. The industry is no longer building, has committed to paying out earnings and doesn’t face the same extent of inventory seen in previous cyclical downturns.

BE

Strategy at the majors is dead, for now. Still the case, or more accurately strategy has narrowed into balance sheet protection. RIO and BHP have slightly better balance sheets, but face a strategic “Catch 22”: they have room for acquisitions only if markets continue to improve, a scenario that is unlikely to force tier 1 assets out of peers. Glencore looks like the only active dealmaker (as a seller of assets) in 2016, while Anglo looks like running a jumble sale for the next six months. Vale’s move to align itself with Fortescue Metals Group (FMG) looks full of hurdles.

BE

Capital allocation needs rethinking. Done. For those of us with long memories of management unwillingness to acknowledge the problems of progressive dividends and pro-cyclical buybacks, the sudden conversion to the logic of pay-out ratios is not without irony. But at least the need to protect balance sheets has led to a convenient embrace of change.

11:18 am
BE

At the moment it is a capacity, not an inventory hangover. Still true. Despite the very poor sentiment at the beginning of 2016, much of it driven by China, the fundamentals of key commodity markets were simply not that bad: inventory trends are nothing like those seen in previous demand downturns. Our thematic work into downstream inventory points to the potential for property inventories to force demand back up the value chain, though these are quantifiable and containable in our view. But a rebound in demand in Q2 looks unlikely.

BE

The capex cycle is still unwinding. Even more pronounced than our original note, capex is the clear casualty of the down-cycle. We think capex contracted 34% in 2015 (up from 32% in our original review) and see a further contraction of 25% in 2016 (up from 19% in our original review). This is feeding through to lower operating costs due to falling competition for common resources.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 765.30, down 50.9 (-6.24%), High: 780.50, Low: 757.00, Volume: 4.37m

Equity rally running on fumes

11:19 am
PM

hehehe

BE

After falling by 20% in the first three weeks of January, mining equities have
been on a tear. The FTSE Mining 350 index is up by 23% YTD and up by 54%
since it reached its 10-year low on 20 January. By comparison, the Bloomberg
Commodity Index (BCOM) is flat YTD, the copper price is up 5% and iron ore is
up 33%. The mining index has therefore outpaced the relevant metals but, even
so, the index is still 8% below the financial crisis nadir. Nevertheless, the rally
has come too soon, too fast, in our view. The necessary remedies to weak
commodity/industry fundamentals – namely, acceleration in supply cuts, aided
by industry consolidation as well as a stabilisation of demand – have not yet
taken effect. What concerns us most is that the mining sector rally has not been
accompanied by an improvement in earnings expectations. Quite to the contrary,
consensus EBITDA estimates (CY16E) have fallen by 10% YTD. The Mining
Index has historically traded at a 15% discount to the FTSE All-share index. At
the beginning of January, that discount had widened to 30%; a level not seen
since 2011. However, over the space of six weeks, that discount narrowed to
only 10% yesterday. Without a meaningful upgrade to sector earnings – unlikely
in our view (spot EBITDA shows 4% downside) – we expect the equities to hit a
valuation air-pocket with some miners heading lower as multiples compress and
normalise.

BE

Market focus to shift from beta back to quality

11:20 am
BE

Diversified miners: We expect the market’s fixation with high beta names to
give way as fundamentals fail to catch-up with sentiment. We therefore reiterate
our Outperform on Rio Tinto and Glencore (TP increased to £1.80) amongst the
diversified miners as the market refocuses on valuation levels, credible debt
reduction plans and tangible catalysts once the sector rally loses steam. Anglo
American is our favoured short in the peer group, however, we have also
downgraded BHP Billiton and South32 to Underperform on valuation grounds.
Base Metal plays: Amongst the base metals stocks, we have downgraded
Antofagasta to Underperform (TP increased to £3.65) as the stock’s earnings
multiple has reached a 12-year high without any attendant improvement in
copper and company fundamentals. KAZ Minerals is our only remaining
Outperform in the sub-sector as we have downgraded Aurubis to Neutral as the
stock is within reach of our TP.
Gold & Diamonds: We continue to prefer Centamin among gold miners, though
we believe profit taking in the sector is in order following the recent strong rally.
We recently upgraded gemstone miners, notably Petra Diamonds and
Gemfields, in light of stabilizing pricing and midstream inventory restocking. See
Fig 7 for a complete list of recommendation, TP and estimate changes.

BE

Well timed 'Fags downgrade, that.

BE

Canaccord, which doesn't say much.

BE

Valeant reported its long-awaited Q4 this morning, and revised 2016 guidance since
restating earnings. For Q4, revenue of $2.8B was ahead of our $2.7B and consensus'
$2.76B. However, non-GAAP EPS came in at $2.50, missing our estimate of $2.59 and
consensus’ $2.62 – perhaps already anticipated by the stock.
2016 guidance was lower than what we had anticipated: non-GAAP EPS of $9.50 and
$10.50, compared to prior guidance (at December Investor Day) of $13.25 to $13.75,
our (stale) estimate of $13.57 and the Street’s (also stale estimate) of $13.27. The
discrepancy reflects new managed care contracts, back-office investments, revenue
short-falls and inventory destocking that will mostly occur in Q1. As a result, we will be reevaluating
our projections and valuation in a more detailed note to follow.
The stock will likely be weak (although it’s obviously been VERY weak) because of the
light guidance, but we think: 1) with the revised numbers, some near-term uncertainty
is now behind Valeant; 2) Xifaxan will be the engine of growth and we don’t expect Gx
to enter until 2029; 3) there will be more optimism in 2H2016 as the company aims to
focus on volume growth instead of price; 4) TRx trend of major products has not been
affected despite cutting ties with Philidor

BE

And RBC, which doesn't say much.

11:27 am
BE

2016 guidance lowered below our preliminary estimates. Total
revenue guidance was lowered to $11.0-11.2B from $12.5-12.7B
and cash EPS guidance decreased to $9.50-10.50 from $13.25-13.75.
Management is now guiding to $5.6-5.8B in Adj. EBITDA, down from
$6.9-7.1B. Guidance was lowered to reflect reduced revenues from
businesses such as Ophth, ROW Developed, Women's Health, and
Surgical. Management also noted that Q1/16 will be affected by
inventory de-stocking in derm and GI. We note that we anticipated
revenue guidance would be in the $12-12.4B range, EPS in the $12-13/
sh. range, and Adj. EBITDA in the $6.5-6.8B range. We believe the
Street will be surprised by the magnitude of the guidance revision and
anticipate it could cause concern unless it is properly addressed on the
conference call.
• Revenues of $2.79B vs. consensus of $2.76B. Total revenues in Q4/15
were $2.79B vs. our forecast of $2.73B, consensus of $2.76B (FactSet,
17 analysts, $2.70-2.96B range), and guidance of $2.7-2.8B. Full year
revenues were $10.50B vs. $10.4-10.5B guidance and our $10.44B
estimate. COGS of $727MM were ~$200MM above our $539MM
estimate. In process R&D impairment of $140.3MM includes the
$100MM upfront payment in connection with brodalumab. Philidor
related wind-down expenses of $48.8MM were incurred in Q4/15. The
GI business had revenues of $509MM vs. our expected $607MM, and
management attributed the soft sales to reductions in inventory related
to the Walgreens agreement. While we understand derm and ophth destocking
as the shift to Walgreens continues, we believe further clarity
is needed as to how this would significantly affect the GI business.
• Q4/15 cash EPS of $2.50 vs. consensus of $2.62. Valeant reported
Q4/15 cash EPS of $2.50 vs. guidance of $2.55-2.65, consensus of $2.62
(FactSet, 20 analysts), and our forecast of $2.62. Full-year cEPS was
$10.16 vs. guidance of $10.23-10.33 and our estimate was $10.27.
• What we are looking for on the conference call. We anticipate
the conference call will address concerns including the following: (i)
guidance commentary given the magnitude of revision; (ii) updates
on the AdHoc committee's progress; (iii) timing of the 10-K filing;
(iv) updates on SEC probes and other government investigations; and
(v) commentary on plans to enhance market access for products and
defend formulary positions.

5:30 Novice H’cap Chase. ALOOMOMO 11/2 W impressive all 3 chases this season could be double on the day for Warren Greatrex if Out Sam wins earlier; and BALLYALTON 12/1 EW (most firms paying 4 places).

Tullow Oil PLC (TLW:LSE): Last: 196.83, down 19.27 (-8.92%), High: 209.29, Low: 196.40, Volume: 5.93m
11:32 am
PM

oh dear

BE

Their broken ship is increasingly broken.

BE

Jubilee FPSO

11:32 am
BE

Forcing them to choke production by 50%

BE

And put off two crude liftings ahead of the scheduled maintenance on 20th March.

BE

As we've said repeatedly, Tullow's a big bet on operational delivery

11:34 am
BE

If TEN backslides too much, or the cash from Jubilee falls short, you're on for a rights issue.

BE

Which makes it all a bit binary. So while two crude lifts ahead of a maintenance shutdown doesn't really change anything in the scheme of things, it does rather emphasise the binary risk here.

BE

RBC incoming.

11:35 am
BE

Ahead of next week’s maintenance shut-in, and a change in offloading procedure to help address issues associated with offloading without the ability to weathervane the FPSO, Tullow as operator of the Jubilee field has declared force majeure on two crude cargoes, Reuters reported yesterday. This two-week shut-in is reflected in the participants’ FY16 production guidance of ~100,000b/d (gross). Given the logistics involved in a material work-over campaign, we do not expect the issues associated with the turret system to be resolved during this shut-in. Assuming an unscheduled maintenance shut-in later this year, we would note that Tullow as operator has hull and machinery insurance for the joint venture while the individual participants have their own loss of production insurance.

BE

And Deutsche.

BE

This follows investigation into a deteriorated turret bearing on the FPSO that requires new operating procedures to be implemented. Tullow expects to resume normalized liftings in early April with the arrival of a new dynamically positioned shuttle tanker, which is able to hold itself in a single location during crude offtake. Tullow expects only a negligible impact on short-term Jubilee production and no change to its 2016 guidance.

11:36 am
BE

And UBS, from a few days ago, which bought dinner for CEO Aidan Heavey

BE

Messaging on T.E.N. progress,
Jubilee insurance vis-à-vis the turret-bearing issue, and debt refinancing was upbeat.
Heavey sees East Africa farm-out as an event that would solve various strategic issues.
We agree this is a key stock driver for 2016. We like Tullow's portfolio and see Balance
Sheet risk as manageable, but post the recent rally risk-reward seems balanced.

BE

T.E.N.: Heavey is confident of July-Aug' first oil, with the FPSO having arrived early Mar'
from Modec's Singapore yard, on time and with no carry-over work. Well completions
and hook-up are ongoing. Jubilee: investigations into the turret-bearing are ongoing.
Engineers are looking for solutions that would allow in-situ repairs. Spread-mooring is
also being examined and tug-boats can hold the vessel in place ($10m/annum), without
compromising safety. If the bearing needs replacement, or extensive repair is required,
the FPSO may need to be docked, which could see it offline 6-12 months. Heavey,
though, highlighted business interruption insurance (12 months with a 1 month excess)
which should protect against losses (unless the issue is found to be design related).

11:36 am
BE

East Africa: Farm-out of Uganda (currently 33%) and Kenya (50%) is a strategic
priority; Heavey is targeting back-costs plus a development carry. This would provide
upfront liquidity whilst securing a 'zero-cost' production growth profile. Agreement of
pipeline route between various stakeholders would de-risk the project and could act as
a trigger for a transaction. He expects to realise a price at least equivalent to Africa Oil's
farm-down to Maersk. Funding: Net debt stands at $4.0bn and increases to $4.7bn
(UBSe) ahead of T.E.N. first oil. Reducing the burden is a primary focus, but equity is
seen as neither attractive nor necessary, with portfolio management and flexing capex
to '$300m or less' from 2017E preferred levers. The $3.7bn RBL and $1bn RCF need refinancing
by 1Q17E, but Heavey sees the banks supportive given rapid improvement in
credit metrics once T.E.N. is on-stream (Net debt/EBITDA 2016E: 5.3x; 2017E: 3.6x).

BE

That's from the 11th, before this setback

BE

I include it largely because investor dinners do not and cannot involve price-sensitive information, so you've no reason to read any of that.

PM

And Joseph -- being our footnote specialist in chief..

PM

Points me in the direction of item 8.01

PM

The filing of the Company’s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015 will be delayed pending completion of the Company’s
ongoing review of certain historical financial statements. As a result, the Company will not file its Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015 within
the 15-day extension period provided by Rule 12b-25(b). The Company is working diligently and intends to file the Form 10-K as promptly as reasonably
practicable.

11:40 am
BE

Yep.

PM

Under the various indentures governing the Company’s outstanding notes, if the Company does not file the Form 10-K by March 15, 2016, the Company will
be in breach of the reporting covenant in the indentures and the trustee or holders of at least 25% of any series of notes may deliver a notice of default. The
Company then would have 60 days from the date of receipt of a notice of default to file the Form 10-K and thereby cure the default. If the Company does not
cure the default by the end of the 60-day period, the notes may be accelerated by the trustee or holders of at least 25% of the series of notes that provided the
notice of default. The acceleration of one series of notes could result in a cross acceleration to other outstanding series of notes.

The occurrence of a default under the notes would result in a cross default under the Company’s bank credit agreement. The banks would be able to

BE

GS believes recent production data has de-risked forecasts of an oil price
and US rig count recovery in 2017. Our oil team now expects the horizontal
rig count to rise 57% in 2017 and we expect this to drive 9% org. growth for
Weir (20% of US upstream sales). Despite our view that 2016 will mark
trough earnings, Weir trades on 15.8x 2016E P/E (in line with history/sector,
10x 2017E P/E). While the stock has been strong over the last month it has
underperformed peers and our SOTP implies its O&G business is a c.50%
discount to peers. Downside appears limited given 4.2% 2016E div yield, on
our stress test covenants are not breached & dividends are cash covered.

BE

Catalyst
As a result, we reiterate our Buy and add the shares to the Conviction List
with 30% upside. Rig count, which we expect to trough in 2Q, is the key
catalyst. The US horizontal rig count is now at levels not seen since 2006/07,
before fracking was fully commercialized. We believe Weir is currently
pricing a modest rig count recovery of just 10% next year so any indication
that this will be insufficient should support the stock. We remain cautious
on mining aftermarket, and assume a mid-single digit top line decline (in
line with rest of coverage; management expects 2016 to be flattish).
Valuation
Our EBIT estimates fall 1%/9% for 2016/17 as we reflect GS’ latest rig count
forecast, however our 12-month price target remains 1,350p (we roll
forward our estimates). We value Weir using our sector relative EV/IC vs.
ROIC/WACC framework. Our valuation continues to includes an M&A
component at 14x EV/EBIT (based on mining equipment deals over the last
ten years), weighted at 15%.
Key risks
Key risks to our view and price target are worse-than-expected declines in
mining aftermarket, disappointing global oil demand meaning required
shale recovery is lower than expected.

11:49 am
BE

Wood Group's FY results were broadly in-line with pre-existing consensus and - although
the group declined to provide formal guidance - the outlook for this year remains
reasonably positive, with earnings likely to be down no more than 25% despite the major
industry downturn.
We are nonetheless downgrading the stock to a SELL (previously Hold) after
outperformance: our price target is moved back up modestly to 575p (13/12x 16/17E
P/E) reflecting the broader sector rally but we don't believe the current share price fairly
reflects Wood Group's relative merits. We estimate the stock is currently valued at a 5
turn premium to Amec F-W or Petrofac based on 16/17 P/E, and a more than 2 turn
premium to Technip. Impressive as Wood Group's business performance is, we just don't
see this level of premium remaining.

BE

Whilst the bulk of Wood Group's US activity is in operations & maintenance, and a
growing proportion is outside upstream oil & gas entirely, it remains the case that the
group has a much greater exposure to US rig counts than any of its UK listed peers
(except Hunting). In this context we find it surprising that the stock has been so resilient
year-to-date, as US rig counts have been uniformly negative, reaching post-1940s lows in
the past two weeks and looking likely to plumb fresh depths.
Whilst volume is under pressure, what is less well known in many of these markets
is how strong pricing pressure is. One way of looking at this is simply to observe that
despite WTI being below $40/bl - after the recent recovery - there are still over 550 rigs
active onshore North America. This can only be because the relevant owners think they
can produce economically at current prices - which has an obvious read-through to the
pricing for the services WG provides.

BE

North Sea equally bad; international offers limited resilience
Our recent visits to Aberdeen confirm the very poor outlook for the UK North Sea, whilst
WG's international upstream activities offer some short-term resilience but less certainty
in the medium-term. In this context it is unsurprising that the management declined to
offer guidance for 2016: the outlook remains extremely difficult.
Cut to SELL, price target to 575p
We were surprised to see the dividend increased as much as 10%: on the current
trajectory, payout will reach 53% (on adjusted diluted EPS) this year. After many years of
above-sector dividend growth we think this source of performance is now exhausted. We
are cutting our earnings to reflect continued end market pressures, by 7% for 16/17E.
The stock continues to look expensive, and with above-sector dividend growth now
limited (in our view), we downgrade to SELL.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 235.10, up 3.9 (+1.69%), High: 235.90, Low: 232.70, Volume: 10.05m
BE

Bank sector piece.

BE

At first sight, UK retail-focused banks appear insulated from the impact of
lower commodity prices and macro concerns. However, we believe the
potential second-order impacts stemming from a lower-for-longer interest
rate environment will be significant. In this report, we assess the likely impact
of the low rate environment on net interest income progression at Lloyds
and RBS, assuming product pricing remains at current levels throughout
2017. We incorporate this analysis into our forecasts.

11:53 am
BE

New mortgage pricing has declined significantly over the past two years.
This has two important implications: (1) back book attrition is likely to
accelerate as the availability and pricing of higher-LTV offerings has
improved markedly; and (2) front book yields are likely to compress as
existing borrowers remortgage at significantly lower rates. We estimate
that, net of some offset from liability repricing, this will result in a c.£300
mn (3%) decrease in NII at Lloyds, while RBS should be able to more than
offset yield pressure through volume growth (+£600 mn/+9% NII by 2017E).

BE

We analyse the two banks’ funding structures in detail and find that RBS
has a funding advantage, on average paying c.40 bp less for deposits. This
advantage appears structural, driven by RBS’s larger share of current
accounts (18% market share vs. only 8% in mortgages). We believe this
underpins RBS’s aggressive growth ambitions in UK mortgages.

BE

RBS shares trade at a 50% discount to LLOY, with a trailing P/TBV of 0.65x
vs. 1.34x. In our view, the valuation gap is likely to narrow as: (1) RBS
continues running down legacy IB assets, which are a meaningful drag on
current profitability; and (2) RBS pursues an aggressive growth strategy in
UK mortgages, allowing it to continue to expand NII and earnings.
Furthermore, RBS appears better positioned to withstand increased
competition in the mortgage lending market owing to its comparatively
small back book and structural funding advantage.
We upgrade RBS to Buy from Neutral and add the stock to our Conviction
List. Key risks relate to litigation and conduct costs, regulatory changes and
competition. We revise our estimates and price targets for both banks,
principally to reflect our NII analysis.

BE

FY15 results are 3% better than consensus in terms of cash flow with guidance for 2016 also a little above expectations. The dividend is up a confident 19% (in line) – with future dividends to reflect the group’s medium-term underlying business growth – again much as expected. The Solvency II ratio is exactly in line with our forecast at 169%, but where the methodology is conservative. If it were presented in the same way as Aviva’s (Buy, tgt 610p), we estimate it would be 174%. Though not as overtly comfortable as some, we remain of the view that this is not a material constraint on sales and that concerns are more than reflected in a 6.0% 2016e yield. We remain buyers.

BE

Net cash generation came in at £1256m (+14% YoY, vs consensus at £1217m and DBe of £1236m). Splitting this out, operational cash flow grew 11% to £1217m (c’sus £1201m); new business surplus was £39m (c’sus £16m) – with the main positive surprises being in annuities (on the in-force book) and protection (on new business). The group is guiding to 6%-7% growth in the life assurance in-force cash flows in 2016 (equivalent to 10% if we adjust for the loss of the tax credits). Assuming no change to our forecasts for other parts of the business, we think this implies c.10% growth in cash flow in 2016e or c.3% uplift to consensus.

11:57 am
BE

Dividend lifted +19%. New policy much as expected
The dividend was lifted 19% to 13.4p, in line with the 1H uplift, and giving cash cover of 1.58x. Looking forward, management has indicated that its new dividend policy will be ‘progressive’ and will reflect the ‘expected medium-term underlying business growth, including net cash generation and operating earnings’. The change in policy was expected, and – based on management’s cash flow guidance for 2016e – looks supportive of the 9% we currently build in for this year.
Solvency II ratio 169% - conservatively calculated
The group’s Solvency II ratio will undoubtedly be the main debate. At 169% this is in line with our own forecast, but compares with a wide range of estimates congregating between 160%-180%. Sensitivities are a bit higher than we had forecast (-11pts for a 100bps fall in risk-free, -4pts for a 20% fall in equities, -1pt for a simple 100bps rise in credit spreads, with extra disclosure around default assumptions); but against this the ratio is calculated on a conservative basis including the with-profits fund at 1x its SCR. If this were excluded as some UK rivals have done, we estimate that the ratio would be more like 174%. Either way, our analysis suggests that the ratio will rise each year even on annuity sales of up to £4bn; our expectation is that management will guide on the expected roll-forward in its presentation.

 Solvency II ratio came in at 169% and compares with our forecast of
c. 180%. In our view this is relatively a weaker capital position within
the UK life insurers as insurers like Aviva, Prudential, Standard Life
(adjusted) all reported higher ratios compared to LGEN. In our view,
LGEN has a higher risk balance sheet compared to Standard Life and
Aviva and thus a ratio lower than that is less impressive to us.
 DPS grew by 19% YoY to 13.4p and is inline with consensus of 13.34p
and 1% below JPMe. Management is guiding for a progressive dividend
policy going forward which would be dependent on growth in the
business, net cash generation and operating profits. We remain
comfortable with our 5% DPS growth in coming years at the moment.
 Net cash generation came in at £1,256m and is 3% ahead of consensus
and 4% ahead of JPMe. The entire beat came from higher than expected
earnings from annuities and better than expected new business strain.
Cash earnings from protection, savings, LGA were all weaker than
expected whereas earnings at LGIM was inline with JPMe and
consensus. Overall annuities continues to remain a driver of growth at
LGEN in our view.
 Annuities volumes were materially weaker than expected as total
annuities premium in 2015 came in at £2.7bn versus our expectation of
£3.3bn. Management mentioned that the new business will closely
follow the internal hurdle rate return which in our view would remain
challenging under Solvency II. Net inflows in annuities in 2015 were
£0.4bn reflecting marginal growth in annuities in 2015.
